title: 108_hr4843
content: The "Federal Wetlands Jurisdiction Act of 2004" clarifies the jurisdiction of the Federal Government over waters of the United States, aims to provide consistency nationwide in determining this jurisdiction, and consolidates the authority to implement the permitting program under the Federal Water Pollution Act. Section 404(a) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to clarify the issuance of permits for waters of the United States, including navigable waters, hydrologically connected waters, and wetlands adjacent to navigable waters. The amendment to Section 404(a) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act clarifies that waters hydrologically connected to navigable waters include perennial or intermittent streams contributing flow, but exclude sheet flow, ephemeral waters, groundwater, manmade ditches, pipelines, and municipal separate storm sewers. The amendment to Section 404(a) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act clarifies that connecting waters, such as sheet flow, ephemeral waters, groundwater, manmade ditches, pipelines, and municipal separate storm sewers, are not subject to the permitting program. Fastlands are also exempt from the jurisdiction of the permitting program. Requests for jurisdiction determination can be submitted to the Secretary by property owners or authorized individuals. Property owners or authorized individuals can request the Secretary to determine the presence of waters of the United States under the permitting program within 90 days of submission. Additional information may be requested within 30 days of the initial request. The Secretary must make a jurisdictional determination for requested waters within 90 days of the initial request, or 60 days after receiving additional information. The determination must be provided in writing with a basis for the decision. Authorized individuals can seek immediate judicial review of the determination. Authorized individuals can seek immediate judicial review of jurisdictional determinations for property in the United States District Court where the property is located, or proceed through the administrative appeals process. Review, relief, or appeal can be sought for any waters described in paragraph (2)(A). The text chunk discusses the option for judicial review, injunctive relief, or administrative appeal for waters described in specific paragraphs. It also mentions the right to seek judicial review in the United States District Court following the administrative appeals process. SEC. 4. SINGLE AGENCY IMPLEMENTATION. Beginning on the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency's authorities under section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act are transferred to the Secretary of the Army. The Administrator retains the authority to comment on permits issued under section 404(a) and general permits issued under section 404(e). All funds appropriated to the Administrator for these authorities are transferred to the Secretary. Conforming amendments are made to section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The Administrator's authorities under section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act are transferred to the Secretary of the Army. Amendments are made to section 404, including changes to subsections (b), (c), and (q) regarding permit decision-making processes. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. Section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1344) is amended to include definitions for "navigable," "wetlands," and "adjacent wetlands." Navigable waters are those used for interstate commerce, wetlands are lands with hydric soils inundated by water, and adjacent wetlands are wetlands physically touching other wetlands. The curr_chunk defines terms related to wetlands, including adjacent wetlands, culvert, and fastlands. Adjacent wetlands are wetlands physically touching other water bodies, culvert is a structure that conveys streams under linear structures, and fastlands are areas behind manmade structures for commercial, industrial, or residential use.
